words.meaning: The belief in or practice of disinterested and selfless concern for the well-being of others.
examples: Firefighters and nurses are often motivated by altruism.
Some people argue that pure altruism is impossible.

words.meaning: Showing a disinterested and selfless concern for the well-being of others; unselfish.
examples: Her altruistic behavior was an inspiration to us all.
He made an altruistic donation to the charity.

words.meaning: A mixture or blend of different elements.
examples: The band's music is an amalgam of jazz, rock, and blues.
The new curriculum is an amalgam of traditional and modern teaching methods.

words.meaning: To combine or unite to form one organization or structure.
examples: The two companies will amalgamate next year.
He decided to amalgamate his various businesses into one.

words.meaning: The action, process, or result of combining or uniting.
examples: The amalgamation of the two school districts was controversial.
This cultural festival is an amalgamation of different traditions.

words.meaning: The character and atmosphere of a place.
examples: The restaurant had a relaxed and friendly ambience.
I love the historic ambience of this old town.

words.meaning: The quality of being open to more than one interpretation; inexactness.
examples: The ambiguity of the poem's ending makes it more intriguing.
There is some ambiguity in the law on this point.

words.meaning: Open to more than one interpretation; having a double meaning.
examples: The politician gave an ambiguous answer to the reporter's question.
His instructions were very ambiguous.

words.meaning: The state of having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone.
examples: She felt a sense of ambivalence towards her new job.
His ambivalence about the move was clear.

words.meaning: Having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone.
examples: He was ambivalent about the proposal.
I feel ambivalent about leaving home.

words.meaning: The food of the gods in Greek and Roman mythology; something very pleasing to taste or smell.
examples: The dessert tasted like ambrosia.
The scent of the flowers was pure ambrosia.

words.meaning: Pertaining to or worthy of the gods; exceptionally pleasing to taste or smell; divine.
examples: She served an ambrosial fruit salad.
The ambrosial aroma filled the kitchen.

words.meaning: To make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better.
examples: The new policy is intended to ameliorate the effects of the recession.
Steps have been taken to ameliorate the situation.

words.meaning: Past tense of ameliorate; made better.
examples: The reforms have ameliorated the living conditions of the poor.
The patient's condition has ameliorated.

words.meaning: Open and responsive to suggestion; easily persuaded or controlled.
examples: She was amenable to the idea of a compromise.
He is an amenable child who is easy to teach.

words.meaning: To make minor changes to (a text, piece of legislation, etc.) in order to make it fairer, more accurate, or more up-to-date.
examples: The constitution was amended to grant women the right to vote.
He asked to amend his statement.

words.meaning: A desirable or useful feature or facility of a building or place.
examples: The hotel has a wide range of amenities for its guests.
Access to good schools is an important amenity for families.

words.meaning: Having or displaying a friendly and pleasant manner.
examples: He was an amiable and good-natured man.
She has an amiable personality that makes her popular.

words.meaning: Characterized by friendliness and absence of discord.
examples: They reached an amicable settlement of the dispute.
Their divorce was surprisingly amicable.

words.meaning: A friendly relationship.
examples: The two nations have lived in amity for many years.
A spirit of amity existed between the two groups.

words.meaning: An official pardon for people who have been convicted of political offenses.
examples: The government granted an amnesty to all political prisoners.
He was granted amnesty and allowed to return to his country.

words.meaning: Showing, feeling, or relating to sexual desire.
examples: He sent her an amorous letter.
She was not in the mood for his amorous advances.

words.meaning: Without a clearly defined shape or form.
examples: An amorphous cloud of dust floated in the air.
The organization has an amorphous structure.

words.meaning: To gradually write off the initial cost of (an asset) over a period.
examples: The company will amortize the cost of the new equipment over five years.
He decided to amortize his mortgage over 30 years.

words.meaning: Enough or more than enough; plentiful.
examples: There is ample evidence to support his claim.
We have ample time to get to the airport.

words.meaning: Enough or more than enough; plentifully.
examples: Her talents were amply demonstrated in her latest film.
The hotel was amply supplied with towels.

words.meaning: Behave uncontrollably and disruptively (also spelled amok).
examples: The protesters ran amuck through the streets.
After the announcement, the crowd went amuck.

words.meaning: An ornament or small piece of jewelry thought to give protection against evil, danger, or disease.
examples: He wore an amulet around his neck to ward off evil spirits.
The ancient tomb contained a golden amulet.

words.meaning: To have a private reason for doing or being involved in something.
examples: He has no ax to grind; he's just stating the facts.
I think she has an ax to grind with the company.

words.meaning: A thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists, especially a thing that is conspicuously old-fashioned.
examples: The monarchy is seen by some as an anachronism in modern society.
The movie was full of anachronisms, like a knight wearing a digital watch.

words.meaning: Belonging to a period other than that being portrayed.
examples: His anachronistic views on women's rights were shocking.
The anachronistic setting of the play confused the audience.

words.meaning: The inability to feel pain.
examples: The doctor administered a local anesthetic to induce analgesia.
Congenital analgesia is a rare condition.

words.meaning: (of a drug) acting to relieve pain.
examples: Aspirin is a common analgesic.
He took an analgesic to relieve his headache.

words.meaning: Comparable in certain respects, typically in a way that makes clearer the nature of the things compared.
examples: The human brain is analogous to a computer.
The two situations are analogous in many ways.

words.meaning: A person or thing seen as comparable to another. (also spelled analog).
examples: The film is an analogue of the classic novel.
Vinyl records are an analogue form of music storage.

words.meaning: A state of disorder due to absence or nonrecognition of authority.
examples: The country descended into anarchy after the government collapsed.
The classroom was in a state of anarchy.

words.meaning: Something or someone that one vehemently dislikes.
examples: Racial prejudice is anathema to me.
The idea of a tax increase is anathema to most voters.

words.meaning: Providing necessary support to the primary activities or operation of an organization, institution, industry, or system.
examples: Ancillary staff, such as cleaners and porters, are essential to the hospital.
The company provides ancillary services to the oil industry.

words.meaning: Partly male and partly female in appearance; of indeterminate sex.
examples: The pop star was known for their androgynous style.
She has an androgynous beauty.

words.meaning: Lacking in color, spirit, or vitality.
examples: The company's anemic performance was a cause for concern.
He gave an anemic excuse for his absence.

words.meaning: A substance that induces insensitivity to pain.
examples: The dentist administered a local anesthetic before drilling the tooth.
He was given a general anesthetic before the operation.

words.meaning: Strong hostility.
examples: There was a great deal of animosity between the two rivals.
He felt no animosity towards his critics.

words.meaning: Hostility or ill feeling.
examples: The author's animus towards the government is clear in his writing.
There was a palpable animus in the room.

words.meaning: A record of events year by year.
examples: His name will go down in the annals of history.
The annals of the society are kept in the library.

words.meaning: To append or add as an extra or subordinate part, especially to a document; to take for oneself.
examples: The government decided to annex the neighboring territory.
Please annex the report to your email.

words.meaning: To add notes to (a text or diagram) giving explanation or comment.
examples: The students were asked to annotate the poem.
He annotated the manuscript with his own comments.

words.meaning: A note by way of explanation or comment added to a text or diagram.
examples: The book includes helpful annotations for students.
His annotations in the margins were insightful.

words.meaning: To declare invalid (an official agreement, decision, or result).
examples: The court had the power to annul the marriage.
The election results were annulled due to fraud.

words.meaning: Not likely to provoke dissent or offense; inoffensive, often deliberately so.
examples: The politician's speech was anodyne and forgettable.
He made a few anodyne remarks about the weather.

words.meaning: To ceremonially confer divine or holy office upon (a priest or monarch) by smearing or rubbing with oil.
examples: The priest will anoint the new king.
He was anointed as the successor to the company's founder.

words.meaning: Deviating from what is standard, normal, or expected.
examples: The anomalous test results required further investigation.
His behavior was anomalous for someone in his position.

words.meaning: Something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected.
examples: There was a statistical anomaly in the data.
The genetic anomaly caused a rare disease.

words.meaning: To cause (someone) to become hostile.
examples: His comments were sure to antagonize the crowd.
She didn't want to antagonize her boss.

words.meaning: A thing or event that existed before or logically precedes another.
examples: The antecedent of the pronoun 'it' is the noun 'book'.
The events were an antecedent to the war.

words.meaning: Preceded in time; came before (something) in date.
examples: The invention of the printing press antedated the digital revolution.
His ideas antedated the official start of the movement.

words.meaning: Of or belonging to the time before the biblical Flood; ridiculously old-fashioned.
examples: He has some rather antediluvian ideas about the role of women.
My grandmother's kitchen has an antediluvian charm.

words.meaning: A published collection of poems or other pieces of writing.
examples: He edited an anthology of modern American poetry.
The short story was included in a new anthology.

words.meaning: The belief that human beings are the central or most important entity in the universe.
examples: Environmentalists often criticize anthropocentrism.
Anthropocentrism can lead to a disregard for other species.

words.meaning: An expert in or student of anthropology.
examples: The anthropologist studied the customs of the remote tribe.
Margaret Mead was a famous anthropologist.

words.meaning: Grotesque or bizarre.
examples: The clown's antic behavior made the children laugh.
His antic gestures were distracting.
